Award.AwardTitle: REU Site: Physics Research at Brigham Young University
Award.AbstractNarration: This award supports an REU / RET site in physics at Brigham Young University. Participating students will engage in a ten-week summer physics research program in computational plasma physics, ultrafast nonlinear optics, experimental and computational condensed matter physics, x-ray and XUV sources and optics, microfabrication technology, metrology, astronomy, or materials science. Participating students will have the opportunity to experience the joy of research by being involved in all aspects of a research project from proposal presentation through performing the research and reporting their results. The program will focus on developing students' abilities and interest in physics research by hands-on experiences. There will also be some direct mentoring and group training to help the students acquire the skills they will need to get started in their research projects. Group training will include instruction in experimental and computational techniques, sensitivity to experiences of underrepresented groups in the disciplines, preparation for graduate school, and scientific writing and presentations. Students will also benefit from close and direct mentoring by faculty members involved in their research projects. This contact will give them role models for professional ethics and standards and opportunities to discuss many aspects of graduate school opportunities and careers in physics and related fields. The site will also include an RET program involving three secondary school teachers. The teachers will work alongside the REU students in similar research projects under the supervision of faculty mentors.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Our project involved hosting a total of 33 undergraduate students and 7 secondary teachers in a 10-week summer research experience. All of the participants had an opportunity to design a research project, conduct their research, and report on their results in oral and written form. Many of the participants had an opportunity to present their results in a professional conference or to jointly author a publication which included their results. The projects spanned a wide range of physics and astronomy disciplines including extreme ultraviolet optics, visible and radio astronomy, materials science, nanoparticles, quantum dynamics, plasma physics, thin film mechanical properties, matter wave interferometry, magnetic resonance, linear and nonlinear acoustics, and x-ray crystallography. The participants were closely mentored by faculty members and more senior students, usually with daily contact with their mentors. As this was the first research experience for many of the students, they were also given an opportunity to learn skills needed in their research through weekly mini-classes which lasted for an hour or two each week. Additional mini-classes focused on familiarizing the students with faculty research and developing professional skills or preparing for graduate school (applying for graduate school, GRE preparation, writing, ethics, and effective presentations).

An important part of the program were the informal associations between students and between student and faculty members. Using BYU funds, we brought the students and faculty together for barbeques, hikes, and field trips. On these outings, students shared research experiences with each other and had good opportunities for informal conversations with faculty members about professional life as a physicist.

Our surveys and interviews with the students indicated that the experience has a positive impact on participants’ interest in physics, desire to attend graduate school, and in providing a context for their other course work.
